Time: 2 Hrs. ENGLISH – I M.M: 80
General Instructions:

You will not be allowed to write during the first 15 minutes. This time is to be spent in reading the question paper. The time given at the head of this paper is the time allowed for writing the answer. Attempt
all five
questions. The intended marks for questions or parts of questions are given in brackets [ ]. You are advised to spend not more than
30 minutes
in answering
Question 1
and
20 minutes in
answering
Question 2.
Question 1
(Do not Spend more than 30 minutes on this question.)
Write a composition (300-350 words) on any one of the following:- [20]
Write a story which justifies the theme: ‘Success does not move along a straight line’.
Narrate an incident where you made the best use of a bad situation and eventually learnt an important life lesson.
‘T
he harder you work, the luckier you become
’. Express your views either
for
or
against
this statement.
Recently what changes have you seen in people’s attitude towards work? Describe what do you feel about these changes.

Study the picture given below. Write a story or a description or an account of what it suggests to you. Your composition maybe about the subject of the picture or you may take suggestions from it, however there must be a clear connection between the picture and your composition
Question 2
(Do not Spend more than 20 minutes on this question).
Select any one of the following: - [10]

Your Uncle has arrived from abroad and has unexpectedly brought you a wonderful gift. Write a letter to your friend describing the gift and expressing your feelings of joy at having received such a wonderful gift.

You have left behind your cellphone in a Shopping Mall. Write a letter to the Manager to inquire if it has been found. You will have to describe the phone, the time, the place and other relevant details to help the Manager trace your phone.
Question 3
Your school is hosting an inter school cricket tournament. Write a notice informing your school about the event.
Write an e-mail to the Principal of a neighboring school informing him/her of the event and requesting him/her to send the school team to participate.
Question 4
Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions that follow: -
The Calcutta where I was born was an altogether old-world place. Hackney carriages
lumbered

about the city raising clouds of dust, and the whips fell on the backs of skinny horses whose bones showed plainly below their hide. There were no trams then, no buses, no motors. Business was not in the breathless rush that it is now, and the days went by in leisurely fashion. Clerks would take a good pull at the hookah before starting for office, and chew their betel as they went along. Some rode in palanquin, other joined in groups of four or five to hire a carriage in common, which was known as a "share-carriage". Wealthy men had monograms painted on their carriages, and a leather hood over the rear portion, like a half-drawn veil. The coachman sat on the box with his turban stylishly tilted on one side, and two grooms rode behind, girdles of yaks' tails round their waists,
startling
the pedestrians from their path with their shouts of "Hey-you."
Women used to go about in the stifling

darkness of closed palanquins; they shrank from the idea of riding in carriages, and even to use an umbrella in sun or rain was considered unwomanly. Any woman who was so bold as to wear the new-fangled bodice, or shoes on her feet, was scornfully nicknamed "mem-sahib", that is to say, one who had cast off all sense of propriety or shame. If any woman unexpectedly encountered a strange man, one outside her family circle, her veil would promptly descend to the very tip of her nose, and she would at once turn her back on him.

There was no gas in the city, and no electric light. When the kerosene lamp was introduced, its brilliance amazed us. In the evening the house-servant lit castor-oil lamps in every room. The one in our study-room had two wicks in a glass bowl.

By this light my master taught me from Peary Sarkar's First Book. First I would begin to yawn, and then, growing more and more sleepy, rub my heavy eyes. At such time I heard over and over again the virtues of my master's other pupil, Satin, a paragon of a boy with a wonderful head for study, who would rub snuff in his eyes to keep himself awake, so earnest was he. But as for me-the less said about that the better! even the awful thought that I should probably remain the only dunce in the family could not keep me awake. When nine o'clock struck I was released, my eyes dazed and my mind drugged with sleep.

There was a narrow passage, enclosed by latticed walls, leading to the interior of the house. A dimly burning lantern swung from the ceiling. As I went along this passage, my mind would be haunted by the idea that something was creeping upon me from behind. In those days devils and spirits lurked in the recesses of every man's mind, and the air was full of ghost stories. One day it would be some servant girl falling in a dead faint because she heard the nasal whine of Sha
n
k-chum. The female demon of that name was the most bad-tempered devil of all, and was said to be very greedy of fish.
The very atmosphere was so enmeshed in ghostly terrors that I could not put my feet into the darkness under the table without them getting the creeps.
For each word given below choose the correct meaning (as used in the passage) from the options provided: [2]
lumbered
(para
Moved slowly
rushed
ran
Moved speedily

(para

surprising

Which word in the passage is the opposite of ‘
cold
Nasal
stifling
lurked

imly
Answer the following questions briefly in your own words:
Describe briefly the carriages used by wealthy men.
According to the narrator, what was the position of women in the period described by him?
Describe how the houses were lit during the narrator's childhood days.
Who was Satin? Why did the narrator detest him?
What fear would haunt the narrator, while moving through a narrow passage leading to the interior of his house?
In not more than 50 words, state the conditions prevalent in Calcutta as described by the narrator.
Question 5

Fill in each of the numbered blanks with the correct form of the word given in the bracket. Do not copy the passage but write in correct serial order the word or phrase appropriate to the blank space [4]
Example:
decided

Once there was a swallow who ....0.... (decide) not to fly south for the winter. However, when the weather ....1.... (turn) cold, he reluctantly started ....2.... (fly) southwards. in a short time ice began to form on its wings and it fell to earth frozen still.

A cow passed by and ....3.... (drop) its dung on the little swallow. The dung warmed it and defrosted its wings. Warm and happy, able ....4.... (breathe), it started to chirp. Just then a large cat came by and ....5.... (hear) the chirping, found out where it was coming from, clawed away the dung and ....6.... (swallowed) the swallow. The story shows that everyone who ....7.... (drop) dung on you is not necessarily your enemy; everyone who gets you out of the dung is not necessarily your friend; and if you are warm and happy in a pile of dung, ....8.... (keep) your mouth shut.

the tax evaders.
I came
an article about my school in a magazine.
I want to impress
you the need for hard work.

the demonstration.

Europe.

her father in her external appearance.
I dispensed
the services of my maid.
I now c
a
ll
the Chief Guest to speak.
Join the following sentences to make one complete sentence without using
and, but
or
so.
Choose the correct option-:
You should read this poem. You should learn this poem.
You should read this poem to learn this poem.
You should not only read this poem but also learn it.
You should read this poem for learning it.
You should read this poem therefore learn it.
Nehru was a thinker. He was a statesman.
Nehru was a thinker as well as a statesman.
Nehru was not a thinker but statesman.
Nehru was a thinker therefore a statesman.
Nehru was a thinker but also a statesman.
He is going to Kashmir. He intends to stay there for two months.
He is going to Kashmir to stay there for two months.
He is going to
Kashmir
where he intends to stay for two months.
He is going to
Kashmir
since he wants to stay there for two months.
He is going to
Kashmir
for he intended to stay there for two months.
He did not come to school. He did not inform anyone.
He neither came to school nor informed anyone.
Neither did he came to school nor did he informed anyone.
As he did not come to school he did not inform anyone.
He did not inform anyone so he did not come to school.
Choose the correct option to rewrite the following according to the instructions given after each sentence-:
If you do not work hard you will not succeed.
(Use : unless)
Unless you worked hard, you will not succeed.
Unless you working hard you will not succeed.
Unless you work hard you will not succeed.
Unless you don't work hard you would succeed.
A storm will probably be there
(Begin with:
It is probable
It is probable that there will be a storm there
It is probable if a storm will be there
It is probable there will be storm
It is probable that a storm will be there
Nobody in our school is as smart as Uma.
Use
Smarter
Uma is smarter than any other girl in our school.
Nobody in our school is smarter to Uma.
No
body in our school was smarter than Uma.
Nobody in our school is smart as Uma
There are few people in the market today.
(Begin with:
There are hardly
There were hardly any people in the market today.
There are hardly any people in the market today.
There are hardly any few people in the market today.
There are hardly any people in the market this day.
I accept your offer.
Use
acceptable
Your offer is acceptable to me
Your offer was acceptable to me
Your offer is acceptable
Your acceptable offer came to me
I have never Mr. Joe lose his temper
(Begin with:
Never
Never I have seen Mr. Joe lose his temper
Never did I see Mr. Joe lose his temper
Never have I seen Mr. Joe losing his temper
Never ever did I see Mr. Joe lost his temper
As soon as he finishes his work, he starts playing.
(Begin with:
Hardly
Hardly his work is finished, he starts playing
Hardly he finishes his work, he starts playing
Hardly he has finished his work and he starts playing
Hardly does he finish his work when he starts playing
Because of the rough sea, the ship could not sail.
(Use: prevent)
The rough sea prevented the ship from sailing.
The rough sea prevent
s
the sailing of the ship.
The rough sea was preventing the ship’s sail.
The rough sea prevented in sailing the ship.
